item.title: Seoul Lashes Back at North
item.description: South Korea said it would speed up plans to develop missile-defense systems, as President Park Geun-hye called for "strong retaliation" against any provocations by the North.

item.title: Court Upholds Kenyatta Victory
item.description: Kenyans expressed relief on Sunday that a month of electoral uncertainty had passed without the violence that marred past contests, after their Supreme Court upheld Uhuru Kenyatta's narrow presidential victory.

item.title: Cypriots Worry Over Younger Generation
item.description: Rural areas trained a generation to work in services, and now that is withering, as did agriculture before it.

item.title: Serbia-Kosovo Talks Seek a Breakthrough
item.description: Leaders from Serbia and Kosovo are set to convene Tuesday to hash out details of a deal that could, over time, transform ties between the estranged Balkan neighbors.

item.title: China Sets Home-Ownership Curbs
item.description: China's political and financial capitals moved to put new restrictions on home ownership, the latest in a series of measures by Chinese officials to stem the formation of a property-market bubble in Beijing and Shanghai.

item.title: Karzai Seeks Qatar's Help on Talks
item.description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai traveled to Qatar in a bid to revive Afghanistan's faltering peace process and patch up relations with the wealthy Gulf emirate where the Taliban are establishing their main negotiating headquarters.

item.title: Egyptian Satirist Grilled for Mocking Morsi
item.description: An Egyptian satirist was released on bail Sunday after he faced questioning on charges of insulting Islam and the country's president.

item.title: Abe Pledges to Beef Up Mongolia Ties
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wrapped up a weekend trip to Mongolia on Sunday, with the two countries pledging greater cooperation in energy and security.

item.title: Pope Makes Easter Plea for Peace
item.description: The new leader of the world's Roman Catholics urged a speedy resolution of the bloody civil war in Syria and an end to a worsening standoff on the Korean peninsula in his first Easter address Sunday.

item.title: Crash Kills China Air Force Pilots
item.description: Two Chinese air force pilots were killed when their Russian-made Su-27 fighter crashed during a training mission, the country's defense ministry said.

item.title: Rescue Efforts Hampered in Tibet Landslide
item.description: Chinese authorities on Sunday reported little progress in the search for survivors from a Friday landslide that state media said buried 83 workers at a mining site in Tibet.

item.title: India's BJP Elevates Modi
item.description: The Bharatiya Janata Party has appointed Narendra Modi to two of its top panels, taking the Gujarat chief minister a step closer to becoming the prime ministerial candidate for India's main opposition party.

item.title: Italy's New Tack on Political Deadlock
item.description: Italy's president said Mario Monti's government should remain in power while a group of experts hashes out a blueprint of reforms for a future government, an unusual gambit that essentially buys time to resolve the country's deep political divisions.

item.title: Three Killed in Two Attacks in Mali
item.description: A suicide bomber attempted to force his way past the defenses of the city of Timbuktu on Saturday, detonating himself, while a land mine exploded in another part of northern Mali, killing a total of three, officials said.

item.title: Cyprus Central Bank Details Pain
item.description: Cyprus's central bank spelled out the financial damage to big deposit holders at Bank of Cyprus, saying they will lose almost 40% of their money. Losses could grow even steeper.

item.title: School Principal Killed in Pakistan
item.description: Suspected Pakistani Taliban killed a school principal and injured several students in Karachi in an attack that highlighted the militants' spreading reach..

item.title: Karzai in Qatar for Peace Talks
item.description: Afghan President Hamid Karzai arrived in Qatar on a trip that Afghan officials have billed as an effort to kick-start a faltering peace process with the Taliban.

item.title: U.S. Hands Over Base to Afghans
item.description: U.S. forces handed over a base in a strategic district of Afghanistan. The move satisfies a demand by President Karzai that U.S. forces leave the area after allegations that the Americans' Afghan counterparts committed human-rights abuses there on U.S. orders.

item.title: Argentina Seeks to Reassure Creditors
item.description: Argentina's government pledged to keep paying its debts after it submitted a proposal to settle with litigating creditors that some analysts say is unlikely to convince the judges who will rule in the case.

item.title: Mandela Is Treated for Pneumonia
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela is being treated for pneumonia but is responding to doctors' efforts while he remains in the hospital for a third day, South Africa's presidency said.

item.title: Belgium Reaches Deal on Spending
item.description: Belgium reached a deal to curb government spending and sell €1 billion of state-owned assets in order to meet European Union budget goals.

item.title: Channeling Mrs. Thatcher in Tokyo, Seoul
item.description: Margaret Thatcher's ideas are enjoying a renaissance in Asia, where the new leaders of Japan and South Korea embrace the Cold War-era British leader as a role model.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: 'Finnegans Wake' Is Greek to Many; Now Imagine It in Chinese
item.description: A Chinese translation of the James Joyce novel, in the works for years, has become a modest but clear hit in China.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 31
item.description: In today's pictures, a boy receives communion in South Africa, Easter egg hunters go on a spree in Belgium, a rescue worker responds to a mining accident in Tibet, and more.
